summary: While racing toward the town of Red Rock in post-Civil War Wyoming, bounty hunter John "The Hangman" Ruth (Kurt Russell) and his fugitive prisoner (Jennifer Jason Leigh) encounter another bounty hunter (Samuel L. Jackson) and a man who claims to be a sheriff. Hoping to find shelter from a blizzard, the group travels to a stagecoach stopover located on a mountain pass. Greeted there by four strangers, the eight travelers soon learn that they may not make it to their destination after all.

reviews.content: Perhaps the best remake yet of 1982's The Thing.  A taught, claustrophobic/paranoid death fest during a winter storm, starring Kurt Russell with music by Ennio Morricone.  Essentially a group of people trapped inside a 'facility' in the middle of nowhere, distrusting each other, killing and being killed off one by one, as adeptly handled by Tarantino as it was by Carpenter.  You can argue that this one has women in it, but most of them are easily counterparts to the chess computer, while Daisy is not a woman at all but the Thing in itself.
Disappointing to say the least. It could have been better. It should have been better.
one of my favourite Tarantino movies

The Hateful Eight is a very nuanced yet awesome entry into the Tarantino filmography. The way he uses only a number of settings to carry a three hour long story is very impressive and immersive. The story carries and is interesting throughout but may be boring to someone who is expecting a 'shoot-em-up' western style movie. And on top of a great story, setting, and dialogue there is phenomenal acting from Sam L. Jackson, Kurt Russel, Tim Roth, and the rest of them. Definitely worth a watch.

If you're a fan of action and violence, it's a decent film.  Too much Tarantino arbitrarily being Tarantino, by adding asinine details to scenes, causes it to be way too long for me to call it a great movie, but it doesn't ruin it either.  I give it a "C" grade overall.

One of the best western movies of recent times. I grew up watching westerns, specially spaghetti westerns and this is a fantastic resemblance. A very surprising and violent ending keeps you off your seat.

A brutal, mean-spirited modern Western.

Director Quentin Tarantino's Western mystery drama The Hateful Eight (2015) is a fearsome picture with sterling direction from a true lover of Westerns. The bloodletting is like a Sam Peckinpah film with limbs being hacked off and heads getting blown open. The gripping drama and intriguing mystery pulled me into Tarantino's strange Western. His visceral action and absurd black comedy sensibilities makes for a thoroughly enjoyable picture. The Hateful Eight is an underrated Tarantino film that I have only gained enjoyment and appreciation for over the years.

Writer Quentin Tarantino ensures The Hateful Eight is an uncomfortable watch with vile language and evil men constantly spewing cruel hate. He feels particularly mean-spirited as even the seemingly just black hero gets treated horribly by the surrounding racists with the N-word being thrown around with venom alongside sickening swears and heinous insults. Tarantino does not shy away from the hard dynamic of Northerns and Southerns in a post-Civil War era of America being portrayed. Quentin Tarantino's script is witty for his dark humor and I never saw his twist coming. I do appreciate Tarantino establishing how and why the haberdashery was set up in such a particular way in his neat flashback reveal. It is very clever.

Editor Fred Raskin lets the tension build and atmosphere hang in uncertainty. You never know when the blizzard will pick up or a character will quickly draw a pistol in sudden rage or deliberate strategy with Raskin's sharp cuts. His smooth flashbacks and reaction cuts of characters is enthralling. The Hateful Eight is 188 minutes long and felt half that length upon revisiting it as it's all character driven with high stakes.

Cinematographer Robert Richardson shoots gorgeous wide shots on film of the natural mountainside and endless snowy backdrop. Visually, The Hateful Eight reminded me of old Westerns like Sergio Corbucci's The Great Silence or Robert Altman's McCabe & Mrs. Miller. Tarantino takes the sweeping epic wagon journey of John Ford's Stagecoach with various weary travelers stuck together due to tense wintery conditions from John Carpenter's The Thing. Tarantino's homages range from Spaghetti Westerns like Sergio Leone's Duck, You Sucker to even Agatha Christie style murder mysteries with suspects trapped together.

Samuel L. Jackson is ultra cool and conniving as the sympathetic Major Marquis Warren. It's hard to see Jackson have to suffer racist characters insulting his awesome and inspired black hero Major Warren. He fits his role with an intellectual deductive reasoning like a good detective and a violent tendency to outgun or outsmart his nemesis in every maneuver and moment. Jackson is clearly having fun saying Tarantino's outrageous dialogue and acting out his ultra violent gunplay.

Kurt Russell is very funny as the paranoid and confident John Ruth the Hangman. Russell was just born to play in hardened Westerns. Jennifer Jason Leigh is truly crazy as condemned criminal Daisy Domergue with her racist ranting and vile cunning as she plays the men against one another. She's so funny in The Hateful Eight and a good sport about pretending to be beat up or bloodied up for a lark. Her singing is pretty and she's just lovely in The Hateful Eight as an insane and ruthless crook with a lack of morals.

Walton Goggins is hilarious as the Southern racist Sheriff of Red Rock Chris Mannix. He's a superb foil for Jackson's Major Marquis Warren. He steals many scenes. Demián Bichir's pleasant and suspicious Señor Bob is fun, especially opposite Jackson's Major. Tim Roth's friendly hangman Oswaldo Mobray just immediately feels like he has ulterior motives. Michael Madsen's mysterious cowboy Joe Gage just feels sinister immediately. Bruce Dern's bitter old racist Confederate General Sandford "Sandy" Smithers is excellent. He's truly vile and hateful in a fun performance, especially when he starts cowering in fear and disgust at Samuel L. Jackson's ruthlessly inflammatory story about his son.

Channing Tatum is chilling as the charming, calm, and confident gang leader Jody Domergue, ready and waiting in hiding. James Parks' complaints as stagecoach driver O.B. Jackson is quite funny, especially when he has to go out in the cold. Zoë Bell is super sweet and friendly as Six-Horse Judy. Gene Jones' pleasant old man Sweet Dave is nice like Dana Gourrier's playful Minnie Mink. Keith Jefferson is sympathetic as the poor black man Charly, unfortunately gunned down begging for life.

Production designer Yohei Taneda creates an old wooden stagecoach and cozy wooden haberdashery for The Hateful Eight's main set pieces. Art direction from Richard L. Johnson, Benjamin Edelberg, and Kil Won Yu come out the gate swinging with the beautiful Jesus statue shot with the stagecoach rushing past on its way to hellish scenarios. From snow covered backdrops to ornate interiors, The Hateful Eight looks striking. Set decorator Rosemary Brandenburg stuffs the haberdashery full of furs, snowshoes, blankets, whiskey, and an assortment of candy and other knick-knacks for authenticity. 

I love the practical gore effects from Greg Nicotero. Composer Ennio Morricone delivers another brilliant Western film score. His music sounds ominous and haunting. He builds a sense of foreboding that does not let up until the quiet conversations. I love Ennio Morricone's film scores for all of his iconic Western films, especially the ones directed by Sergio Leone. I loved hearing Jennifer Jason Leigh's cute country folk song on acoustic guitar too.

Costume designers Carole Zacek, Courtney Hoffman, Jonny Pray, Tricia Yoo, Joshua Coleman, Bob Moore Jr., and Marina Marit deliver cool outfit after outfit. From Union and Confederate uniforms or fur laden cowboy gear, The Hateful Eight gives each man and woman a totally unique Western costume. The hardened looks and old era facial hair from make-up artists Greg Funk, Heba Thorisdottir, and Molly Tissavary look awesome. I loved Samuel L. Jackson's mutton chops.

Overall, The Hateful Eight is underrated and underseen among Tarantino's illustrious filmography.

I'm a huge fan of Quentin Tarantino, but this is my least favorite of his films. It's absolutely gorgeous to look at in ultra widescreen HD, especially the outdoor scenes. And there's the usual Tarantino dialogue, with Jackson delivering most of the great banter.

It's just too damn long, by a half hour at least. After a while it gets tedious watching all the different ways to kill people. Yes, that's a Tarantino trademark, but here it seems to be the main point of the film's second half, with the thin plot mostly forgotten. 

I've seen it three times. It doesn't improve with repeated viewings.

90/100 - Fantastic movie. The score, the acting, the plot. Everything is great. It's a film meant for movie buffs who appreciate a story well told. It's long, but well worth the watch and rewatching. Something I like to turn the lights off to, get some hot cocoa, and get under a comfy blanket as I prepare to be entertained for 3 hours. Long movies are hit or miss, and this one is a winner. You dont feel it dragging on, the story is engaging and keeps you feeling a whole range of emotion. There's action, comedy, mystery, history, drama all wrapped in one. Follow Samual L Jackson and Kurt Russell in a snow covered adventure. Also the people doing the set design do a fantastic job. A tarantino classic.

The Hateful Eight is a fantastic western tale of deception that I loved. Only Quentin Tarantino can fill almost an entire movie with just dialogue while still being captivating and engaging.

From start to finish, this film is filled with witty dialogue and dry humor that had me genuinely cracking up. The characters are all stereotypes on a comedic level, but when the writing is this good, they become much more than that. Each character had some level of depth and uniqueness that gave this somewhat dry and slow plot a spark that continually kept the flame of the story burning.

Samuel L. Jackson is brilliant, this movie was directly written for him, and he makes use of every second of screen time he is given. His comedic delivery is excellent and towards the end of the movie his slyness and witty detective work are mesmerizing. Kurt Russell is hilariously stupid and his relationship with his captee (Jennifer Jason Leigh) is hilarious, sweet, and sometimes demented. Walton Goggins was so damn funny here; this is my favorite performance by him. He makes this movie, and the ending resolution would not be the same without him. Tim Roth was awesome, and all the other gang members were great too. The only one that kind of stuck out was Channing Tatum. I do not know if it was my bias of his based on his previous work, but I did not buy him in this film. Felt really out of place and unnecessarily cast on his name sack alone.

Despite the slow pace and long runtime, this film is an utter masterpiece that keeps the viewer engaged and constantly curious about what the true motivations are behind each of our eight characters. The chapter-like structure is fantastic and there are some Pulp Fiction elements here in terms of storytelling order which I loved. While this may not be Tarantino's best film, it is still an incredible product and another classic added to his filmography.

Score: 90%
Verdict: Excellent

Main complaint: this movie could've been an hour shorter, and the long runtime isn't anywhere near worth the payoff. The first hour is just characters introducing each other, with the same people using the same introductions multiple times. The movie is set up to be a high-tension murder mystery but then quickly changes into blatant violence. I know violence is Tarantino's thing, but the sudden change in tone of the movie was too abrupt, especially because the set-up for the first half was so long. Then the violence half wasn't anything special, almost all of the characters die from close range bullets. Overall, it's just a bad movie that made me feel guilty for making my partner sit down and watch the whole thing.

Unlike most people who would probably argue that 'Pulp Fiction' is Tarantino's finest film, I would say this one is hands down. It effectively keeps us in the dark and on the edge of our seats until the moment it actually needs to reveal itself and even after it does we're already pretty hooked with the brilliant crass banter the happens from the get go between the movie's colorful characters, including that oh so glorious line from Samuel L that makes me want to stand up and physically applaud while screaming out '@#$% YES!'... anyone who's seen the movie will certainly know which line I'm talking about.

My main fault with the movie is pretty much all of the characters have some quality that makes me not want to root for them. But looking past that, very solid film. 7.8/10

I was least satisfied with and least excited for, The Hateful Eight when I saw it back in 2016. Although not the same exact time period as Django — that being antebellum South, this being postbellum West — it was too similar and I had wanted something completely different; It's not like Tarantino comes out with a film every year. The Tarantino film I've probably seen the least amount of times, The Hateful Eight pleasantly surprised me on this most recent viewing, scoring an (85), anchored with the acting from a phenomenal cast. I mean, every single actor elevated the so-so plot. Kurt Russell (and his John Wayne-like accent), Samuel L. Jackson, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Tim Roth, and Bruce Dern all deserve praise, but Walton Goggins as Chris Mannix was by far the stand-out here. Part Western, part Murder-Mystery, the film's plot and structure was still strange and overindulgent. This does not need to be a 168-minute movie. An issue I had was when John Ruth (Russell) determines that at least one-person is in cahoots with Daisy (Leigh), why doesn't he just shoot her in the head? I get it, he's John "The Hangman" Ruth, but it was really stupid he would keep her alive after this revelation. Either 1. Make her "alive" bounty worth more than the "dead" so it gives him a financial motive, or kill off Ruth before he ever acquires knowledge of conspiracy. While Samuel L. Jackson's overall performance is excellent, there were moments after he had been shot in the groin where he acted as if he weren't in any pain whatsoever. The quintessence of the overindulgence in THE came with Tarantino's narration — it simply wasn't necessary and didn't add anything to the film, as is so often the case with such narration. The film also has a thrilling, original score. At an (85), The Hateful Eight actually has the second lowest of all my Tarantino scores (Deathproof at (84) is the lowest), but if you follow my lists, you know that those are very high overall and a testament to QT the god.
Fine performances all around, but The Hateful Eight doesn't stand out as much as other Quentin Tarantino films. 4.25/10

One of the best looking of Tarantino's films, everything about this is beautiful to look at. The staging of cramped interiors and sweeping vistas alike is striking and involving, all in service of character and plot. The theatricality of the whole thing could easily become irritating or aimless, but the performances - with the possible exception of Tim Roth - really make it work. I should find it too long, because like almost all his films it objectively is too long - but I do like this film very much. It all hands together so well, the characters are utterly beguiling and the plot spools at just the right pace. He just really needs to stop casting himself in even the smallest of parts in his films.
It's a bit more thoughtfully crafted and plotted then some of Tarantino's previous entries and it's greatly lifted by an ensemble cast of powerhouse presences.

Having seen Django Unchained before this, and already being a big fan of the Western genre, I expected a lot from this movie and it certainly delivered. It follows the story of 8 people inside this log cabin through a snowstorm with little truly known about any of them as lying is a big part of the plot. Thanks to minimal locations (i.e. a singular log cabin) the characters are fleshed out very well and equally well portrayed by their respective actors, Samuel L. Jackson's performance was particularly good. Tension in this movie was also something that made it so good, as the movie went on the atmosphere in the cabin got increasingly tense and leads to outbursts of signature Tarantino-style action. The movie overall feels very well-rounded and makes a rewarding watch when coupled with its smarter storytelling. What you need to keep in mind however, is that this movie is an extremely slow-burn, as in the movie is powered by dialogue. Because the movie is so long the vast majority of it is made up talking and only bursts of action in the last hour and a half. This is by no means a bad thing once you get into it, but could be surprising if you expected a Django-type western from Tarantino or even a classic one. Overall, this movie really stands out in Tarantino's collection and is a must-see for fans of his work and sense of humor.

The Hateful Eight feels like classic Tarantino, guiding scenes with dialogue that have unexpected but inevitable conclusions. It's satisfying enough for film lovers and Tarantino fans alike, but not his best work.

The Hateful Eight is the least successful in Tarantino's repertoire and I don't mean financially. This film just seems to have little to no likeability, and before you say it, I do understand that each character is ‘hateful' but at times it seems quite forced. 

Though well written and acted, it feels that the shocking moments are put in there simply to shock rather than provide any interest. We have the story of eight characters trapped in a cabin during a snowstorm, the film is Western themed, there is a revenge plot as well a bounty hunter. I really do not think this is a bad film in any regard, and it even feels like the sister film to Reservoir Dogs, but in terms of style and content it feels like a mishmash of things the audience has seen before from the Director, like his greatest hits, rather than a new and original story.

I am a little caught on one detail Mr. Tarantino. The artificial spotlights inside of Minnie's is very distracting to me. So much hard work went into authenticity… which is why I have to wonder if this was intentional to add a hint of theater to the ambience?  And the mystery continues to unravel…

When Oswaldo appeared, I was like "Why this isn't Christoph Waltz. It's him!"...and then something happened.

No, but, for real, it was a big surprise. I wasn't expecting something wonderful considering the fact that it is the least beloved Tarantino movie. At the end, I'm screaming at the people saying it is not one of the best Tarantino. It feels so different yet so similar. The characters look like the ones in Django and there is liters of bloody blood. Strange thing: No feet! But it really innovates. It's sort of a "Then, There Were None" except there is so much style, complexity and a so much interesting, stressing atmosphere. I was glued to the screen for 3 hours because of these elements. I mean Ennio Morricone was at his level. The complexity of the storyline is surprisingly rich. Divided in six chapters, I loved the way everything was brang to us. Lots of surprises and twists. The acting is on top. And that's pretty much what I had to say about it.

I believe when people review Tarantino movies, they are sometimes reviewing his current movies against his old movies and that is unfair. The Hateful Eight should not be compared to Django Unchained or Pulp Fiction or anything else he's done. It should be reviewed as a movie on its own and it's a brilliant movie. 

The Hateful Eight, like many of his movies, has a lot of interesting characters that keeps you guessing to the very end. NOTHING in this movie is predictable and I love that. And like many Tatantino movies, you become emotionally invested in almost every character in no time at all. There are endless small things he includes about each character that never appears to be exposition. And again, I love that. It's a lost art.  
Even the characters you only see for a short time, you become invested in: Minnie, Six Horse Judy, Sweet Dave and Charly, are just people who enjoy their jobs, enjoy people and want only to please their customers at Minnie's Haberdashery. Poor O.B. is a great driver of a team of horses and is willing to go out in the cold time and time again. - You become invested emotionally in the bad guys too. There is "Bob" the cold-blooded killer and gang member, who can play Silent Night on the piano and can enjoy a good cigar. The highly racist General Sanford Smithers, who only wants to give his son a proper tombstone. Daisy Domergue, the notorious gang member can play guitar and sing well, and you can see the love between her and her brother Jody (for a brief moment). And the main characters, no matter how gruff and crude, you feel for too. John "The Hangman" Ruth is a cold-blooded bounty hunter, but he picks of two freezing people in the snow, wipes some food off of Daisy's mouth, and doesn't like to "cheat the hangman," so he's a fair man as well. Oswaldo Mobray is played by Tim Roth, so of course, he's eccentric and likable. And Major Marquis Warren goes through life a wanted, unappreciated war veteran, who carries a fake letter from Lincoln to help make his way through life in "white America." 

Like most of Tarantino's movies, it is watchable over and over and over. You learn something new and see something you didn't notice before with each viewing.

I feel the first half of the film was excellent but the second half decended into the usual over the top violence for the sake of violence we always get from Tarantinos more recent films. 
I long for the days of Reservoir dogs and Pulp Fiction where the violence actually mattered and was meaningful instead of existing for pure spectacle. I feel like Tarantino is trying too hard to shock us with his use of gore. We watch someone's head explode and we're supposed to be impressed. 
The forced oral sex scene is where the film takes its downturn. It's disturbing, unnecessary, and made me lose all respect for Samuel L Jackson's character so I was no longer rooting for him.
However, the performances were excellent from the entire cast. The music was brilliant as expected as Ennio Morricone wrote the score, and I really liked the snowy blizzard setting.

I love some of Tarantino's work but the quality of his movies has really declined in recent years and The Hateful Eight is the best example of this. It's a dreadful film nearly three hours long, but somehow it manages to feel even longer. It's unbelievably boring, and its treatment of women is unbelievably regressive. The violence is particularly sadistic, even for Tarantino. Violence in his older movies didn't bother me because they had more of a black comic tone and were more satirical in general, but in this movie it was entirely gratuitous. The dialogue was also incredibly uninteresting. Getting through this movie was a real chore. One star because the Ennio Morricone score is pretty fantastic, I have to admit.

I think this is a much maligned film and I am not sure why. I love Quinton Tarantino movies, but this is by far my favorite. The dialogue is so good, the acting by everyone is fantastic, and it's a perfect feel for a western dark comedy. I suppose an apt microcosm of the very worst that drives American ideology. Sort of a petri dish for America's id. The cast delivers on what QT wants, Samuel L. Jackson and Walton Goggins most especially. But dramatically and cinematically, this thing's an over-indulgent dud.

Tarantino when he's at his best, especially when it comes to unpredictability. Well written when it comes to dialogue and character conflicts. Impressive how well he manages to create drama and intensity in such a limited setting for so long. The score is also very good.

Tarantino's ability to write and direct strong, interesting, and violent films has been unquestioned since the debut of his first, Reservoir Dogs, and The Hateful Eight has no exception. The film that I expected to see was just another violent, comedic drama, and by no means is it not. However, the Hateful Eight also ended up transforming into an exciting and intriguing murder mystery, with an unbelievable amount of well-used tension. The ultimate star of the show is obviously taken by Samuel L Jackson who displays a true standout performance. Jackson's performance is paired well with the tense relationship of Kurt Russel's and Walton Goggins' characters. The story's location could not have been more perfect, a snowed-in shack, in which inevitably highly raises the tension. However, the pacing does seem quite slow for a film of this magnitude, which does not help justify it's 3 hour run-time. All in all, it may not be his best work, but, it is still a true Tarantino. 
8/10

The story of this movie take place in Wyoming after the time of Civil War in United States. Due to hazardous blizzard and several incidents, bounty hunter Marquis (Black) rides on a wagon with John, who is also a bounty hunter (White) and Chris, who claimed to be the new sheriff in town (White), along with John's prisoner, Daisy who is a famous criminal (White). The blizzard got harder, so they decided to stop at Minnie's Haberdashery which is a place where people stays during the extreme weather. When they arrived, there were four travelers there. They are Joe who claimed to be a ransom guy who is gonna visit his mother (White), Bob who claimed to be Minnie's substitute during Minnie's vacation (Mexican), Oswaldo who claimed to be the hangman in town (white) and General Smithers who is a famous southern general arrived here to prepare his son's funeral (White) . During the time that everybody gathered in the shack, people split into two groups. One group represent the north side, Marquis is the head of the group. One group represent the south side, general Smithers is the head of the group. As Oswaldo suggested, the pub side belongs to the north, the fireplace belongs to the south and the dinner table is neutral.  As a consequence of a few incidents, Marquis and John starts to have their suspicions that the travelers are colluding with Daisy. Due to a quarrel, Marquis killed Smithers. While everyone focused on the murder, somebody poisoned the coffee and that caused the death of John. Marquis and Chris interrogate the rest of Travelers and figured out all of them are in Daisy's gang. Right at this moment, Cody who is Daisy's brother, have been waited in the basement the whole time sneak attacked Marquis and injured him. After the Crossfire, Marquis and Chris killed all of them beside Daisy.  Since John has the nickname of "The Hangman" and Daisy is John's prisoner. Marquis and Chris hung Daisy.
This movie mainly tackled the racial equation problem. There's a detail that is interesting. In order to prevent Daisy getting saved by her crew, John disarmed Joe and Oswaldo. After that, Joe moved to the table from the fireplace. Even the most innocent character in the show—Minnie who got killed by Cody while setting up the trap for Chris, put up the sign of "Mexicans and Dogs are not allowed" before. She did end up getting rid of it—because she start to allow dogs in her house. The climax of the movie is when Marquis and Chris teamed up against Daisy's crew. They hated each others guts until that point in the movie. Marquis is the black soldier who killed almost forty-seven southern white soldiers. Chris is the son of the southern rebel army leader. They are two people that viewers probably never thought will be on the same side. After Marquis killed the rest of Daisy's crew besides Daisy, she tried to parley with Chris who she knows resents black people. Between the choices of view and justice. Chris chose justice and hung Daisy with the help of Marquis. This ending hinted the wish that director have wish of white people and colored people can be treated equally.
Personally, I love this film. Beside the storyline, the setting of the film is great. Please imagine a Wild Wild West sight taking place in a little shack in a blizzard with all the relationships between all these characters. Hints are also used frequently in this movie, although the first time might be hard to notice. However, after watching it a second time, even smallest thing in the movie means something. Jellybeans on the ground, Jesus's statue and two horses all hinted at something in the end however not understandable at first. If we do not watch it a second time, we will not know the beauty of details in this movie. However, there is are few flaws in the movie. There are a few slow motions clips in the movie and this movie is already three hours long, so that somehow makes it exhausting. Another flaw is actually a mistake they made in the script.  Minnie hates Mexicans nevertheless she welcome Bob in the shack. All in all I think it is great movie.
